an10.29:1.1.pli: “Yāvatā, bhikkhave, kāsikosalā, yāvatā rañño pasenadissa kosalassa vijitaṃ, rājā tattha pasenadi kosalo aggamakkhāyati.
an10.29:1.1.eng: “As far as Kāsi and Kosala extend, and as far as the dominion of King Pasenadi of Kosala extends, King Pasenadi is said to be the foremost.

an10.29:1.2.pli: Raññopi kho, bhikkhave, pasenadissa kosalassa attheva aññathattaṃ atthi vipariṇāmo.
an10.29:1.2.eng: But even King Pasenadi decays and perishes.

an10.29:1.3.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako tasmimpi nibbindati.
an10.29:1.3.eng: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with it.

an10.29:1.4.pli: Tasmiṃ nibbindanto agge virajjati, pageva hīnasmiṃ.
an10.29:1.4.eng: Their desire fades away even for the foremost, let alone the inferior.

an10.29:2.1.pli: Yāvatā, bhikkhave, candimasūriyā pariharanti disā bhanti virocamānā, tāva sahassadhā loko.
an10.29:2.1.eng: A galaxy extends a thousand times as far as the moon and sun revolve and the shining ones light up the quarters.

an10.29:2.2.pli: Tasmiṃ sahassadhā loke sahassaṃ candānaṃ sahassaṃ sūriyānaṃ sahassaṃ sinerupabbatarājānaṃ sahassaṃ jambudīpānaṃ sahassaṃ aparagoyānānaṃ sahassaṃ uttarakurūnaṃ sahassaṃ pubbavidehānaṃ cattāri mahāsamuddasahassāni cattāri mahārājasahassāni sahassaṃ cātumahārājikānaṃ sahassaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ sahassaṃ yāmānaṃ sahassaṃ tusitānaṃ sahassaṃ nimmānaratīnaṃ sahassaṃ paranimmitavasavattīnaṃ sahassaṃ brahmalokānaṃ.
an10.29:2.2.eng: In that galaxy there are a thousand moons, a thousand suns, a thousand Sinerus king of mountains, a thousand Black Plum Tree Lands, a thousand lands west of Godāvarī, a thousand lands north of Kuru, a thousand lands east of Videha, four thousand oceans, four thousand great kings, a thousand realms of the gods of the four great kings, a thousand realms of the gods of the thirty-three, of the gods of Yama, of the joyful gods, of the gods who love to create, of the gods who control what is created by others, and a thousand realms of divinity.

an10.29:2.3.pli: Yāvatā, bhikkhave, sahassī lokadhātu, mahābrahmā tattha aggamakkhāyati.
an10.29:2.3.eng: As far as the galaxy extends, the Great Divinity is said to be the foremost.

an10.29:2.4.pli: Mahābrahmunopi kho, bhikkhave, attheva aññathattaṃ atthi vipariṇāmo.
an10.29:2.4.eng: But even the Great Divinity decays and perishes.

an10.29:2.5.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako tasmimpi nibbindati.
an10.29:2.5.eng: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with it.

an10.29:2.6.pli: Tasmiṃ nibbindanto agge virajjati, pageva hīnasmiṃ.
an10.29:2.6.eng: Their desire fades away even for the foremost, let alone the inferior.

an10.29:3.1.pli: Hoti so, bhikkhave, samayo yaṃ ayaṃ loko saṃvaṭṭati.
an10.29:3.1.eng: There comes a time when this cosmos contracts.

an10.29:3.2.pli: Saṃvaṭṭamāne, bhikkhave, loke yebhuyyena sattā ābhassarasaṃvattanikā bhavanti.
an10.29:3.2.eng: As it contracts, most sentient beings migrate to the realm of streaming radiance.

an10.29:3.3.pli: Te tattha honti manomayā pītibhakkhā sayaṃpabhā antalikkhecarā subhaṭṭhāyino ciraṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ tiṭṭhanti.
an10.29:3.3.eng: There they are mind-made, feeding on rapture, self-luminous, wandering in midair, steadily glorious, and they remain like that for a very long time.

an10.29:3.4.pli: Saṃvaṭṭamāne, bhikkhave, loke ābhassarā devā aggamakkhāyanti.
an10.29:3.4.eng: When the cosmos is contracting, the gods of streaming radiance are said to be the foremost.

an10.29:3.5.pli: Ābhassarānampi kho, bhikkhave, devānaṃ attheva aññathattaṃ atthi vipariṇāmo.
an10.29:3.5.eng: But even the gods of streaming radiance decay and perish.

an10.29:3.6.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako tasmimpi nibbindati.
an10.29:3.6.eng: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with it.

an10.29:3.7.pli: Tasmiṃ nibbindanto agge virajjati, pageva hīnasmiṃ.
an10.29:3.7.eng: Their desire fades away even for the foremost, let alone the inferior.

an10.29:4.1.eng: There are these ten universal dimensions of meditation.

an10.29:4.3.pli: Pathavīkasiṇameko sañjānāti uddhaṃ adho tiriyaṃ advayaṃ appamāṇaṃ;
an10.29:4.3.eng: Someone perceives the meditation on universal earth above, below, across, undivided and limitless.

an10.29:4.4.eng: They perceive the meditation on universal water …

an10.29:4.12.pli: viññāṇakasiṇameko sañjānāti uddhaṃ adho tiriyaṃ advayaṃ appamāṇaṃ.
an10.29:4.12.eng: They perceive the meditation on universal consciousness above, below, across, undivided and limitless.

an10.29:4.13.eng: These are the ten universal dimensions of meditation.

an10.29:5.1.pli: Etadaggaṃ, bhikkhave, imesaṃ dasannaṃ kasiṇāyatanānaṃ yadidaṃ viññāṇakasiṇaṃ eko sañjānāti uddhaṃ adho tiriyaṃ advayaṃ appamāṇaṃ.
an10.29:5.1.eng: The best of these ten universal dimensions of meditation is when someone perceives the meditation on universal consciousness above, below, across, undivided and limitless.

an10.29:5.2.eng: Some sentient beings perceive like this.

an10.29:5.3.pli: Evaṃsaññīnampi kho, bhikkhave, sattānaṃ attheva aññathattaṃ atthi vipariṇāmo.
an10.29:5.3.eng: But even the sentient beings who perceive like this decay and perish.

an10.29:5.4.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako tasmimpi nibbindati.
an10.29:5.4.eng: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with it.

an10.29:5.5.pli: Tasmiṃ nibbindanto agge virajjati, pageva hīnasmiṃ.
an10.29:5.5.eng: Their desire fades away even for the foremost, let alone the inferior.

an10.29:6.1.eng: There are these eight dimensions of mastery.

an10.29:6.3.pli: Ajjhattaṃ rūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati parittāni suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇāni;
an10.29:6.3.eng: Perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, limited, both pretty and ugly.

an10.29:6.4.eng: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

an10.29:6.5.eng: This is the first dimension of mastery.

an10.29:7.1.pli: Ajjhattaṃ rūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati appamāṇāni suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇāni;
an10.29:7.1.eng: Perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, limitless, both pretty and ugly.

an10.29:7.2.eng: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

an10.29:7.3.eng: This is the second dimension of mastery.

an10.29:8.1.pli: Ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati parittāni suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇāni;
an10.29:8.1.eng: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, limited, both pretty and ugly.

an10.29:8.2.eng: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

an10.29:8.3.eng: This is the third dimension of mastery.

an10.29:9.1.pli: Ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati appamāṇāni suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇāni;
an10.29:9.1.eng: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, limitless, both pretty and ugly.

an10.29:9.2.eng: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

an10.29:9.3.eng: This is the fourth dimension of mastery.

an10.29:10.1.pli: Ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati nīlāni nīlavaṇṇāni nīlanidassanāni nīlanibhāsāni.
an10.29:10.1.eng: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, blue, with blue color and blue appearance.

an10.29:10.2.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma umāpupphaṃ nīlaṃ nīlavaṇṇaṃ nīlanidassanaṃ nīlanibhāsaṃ, seyyathā vā pana taṃ vatthaṃ bārāṇaseyyakaṃ ubhatobhāgavimaṭṭhaṃ nīlaṃ nīlavaṇṇaṃ nīlanidassanaṃ nīlanibhāsaṃ;
an10.29:10.2.eng: They’re like a flax flower that’s blue, with blue color and blue appearance. Or a cloth from Varanasi that’s smoothed on both sides, blue, with blue color and blue appearance.

an10.29:10.3.pli: evamevaṃ ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati nīlāni nīlavaṇṇāni nīlanidassanāni nīlanibhāsāni;
an10.29:10.3.eng: In the same way, not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, blue, with blue color and blue appearance.

an10.29:10.4.eng: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

an10.29:10.5.eng: This is the fifth dimension of mastery.

an10.29:11.1.pli: Ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati pītāni pītavaṇṇāni pītanidassanāni pītanibhāsāni.
an10.29:11.1.eng: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, yellow, with yellow color and yellow appearance.

an10.29:11.2.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma kaṇikārapupphaṃ pītaṃ pītavaṇṇaṃ pītanidassanaṃ pītanibhāsaṃ, seyyathā vā pana taṃ vatthaṃ bārāṇaseyyakaṃ ubhatobhāgavimaṭṭhaṃ pītaṃ pītavaṇṇaṃ pītanidassanaṃ pītanibhāsaṃ;
an10.29:11.2.eng: They’re like a champak flower that’s yellow, with yellow color and yellow appearance. Or a cloth from Varanasi that’s smoothed on both sides, yellow, with yellow color and yellow appearance.

an10.29:11.3.pli: evamevaṃ ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati pītāni pītavaṇṇāni pītanidassanāni pītanibhāsāni;
an10.29:11.3.eng: In the same way, not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, yellow, with yellow color and yellow appearance.

an10.29:11.4.eng: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

an10.29:11.5.eng: This is the sixth dimension of mastery.

an10.29:12.1.pli: Ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati lohitakāni lohitakavaṇṇāni lohitakanidassanāni lohitakanibhāsāni.
an10.29:12.1.eng: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, red, with red color and red appearance.

an10.29:12.2.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma bandhujīvakapupphaṃ lohitakaṃ lohitakavaṇṇaṃ lohitakanidassanaṃ lohitakanibhāsaṃ, seyyathā vā pana taṃ vatthaṃ bārāṇaseyyakaṃ ubhatobhāgavimaṭṭhaṃ lohitakaṃ lohitakavaṇṇaṃ lohitakanidassanaṃ lohitakanibhāsaṃ;
an10.29:12.2.eng: They’re like a scarlet mallow flower that’s red, with red color and red appearance. Or a cloth from Varanasi that’s smoothed on both sides, red, with red color and red appearance.

an10.29:12.3.pli: evamevaṃ ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati lohitakāni lohitakavaṇṇāni lohitakanidassanāni lohitakanibhāsāni;
an10.29:12.3.eng: In the same way, not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, red, with red color and red appearance.

an10.29:12.4.eng: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

an10.29:12.5.eng: This is the seventh dimension of mastery.

an10.29:13.1.pli: Ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati odātāni odātavaṇṇāni odātanidassanāni odātanibhāsāni.
an10.29:13.1.eng: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, white, with white color and white appearance.

an10.29:13.2.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma osadhitārakā odātā odātavaṇṇā odātanidassanā odātanibhāsā, seyyathā vā pana taṃ vatthaṃ bārāṇaseyyakaṃ ubhatobhāgavimaṭṭhaṃ odātaṃ odātavaṇṇaṃ odātanidassanaṃ odātanibhāsaṃ;
an10.29:13.2.eng: They’re like the morning star that’s white, with white color and white appearance. Or a cloth from Varanasi that’s smoothed on both sides, white, with white color and white appearance.

an10.29:13.3.pli: evamevaṃ ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati odātāni odātavaṇṇāni odātanidassanāni odātanibhāsāni;
an10.29:13.3.eng: In the same way, not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, white, with white color and white appearance.

an10.29:13.4.eng: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

an10.29:13.5.eng: This is the eighth dimension of mastery.

an10.29:13.6.eng: These are the eight dimensions of mastery.

an10.29:14.1.pli: Etadaggaṃ, bhikkhave, imesaṃ aṭṭhannaṃ abhibhāyatanānaṃ yadidaṃ ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati odātāni odātavaṇṇāni odātanidassanāni odātanibhāsāni;
an10.29:14.1.eng: The best of these dimensions of mastery is when someone, not perceiving form internally, sees forms externally, white, with white color and white appearance.

an10.29:14.2.eng: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

an10.29:14.3.eng: Some sentient beings perceive like this.

an10.29:14.4.pli: Evaṃsaññīnampi kho, bhikkhave, sattānaṃ attheva aññathattaṃ atthi vipariṇāmo.
an10.29:14.4.eng: But even the sentient beings who perceive like this decay and perish.

an10.29:14.5.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako tasmimpi nibbindati.
an10.29:14.5.eng: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with it.

an10.29:14.6.pli: Tasmiṃ nibbindanto agge virajjati, pageva hīnasmiṃ.
an10.29:14.6.eng: Their desire fades away even for the foremost, let alone the inferior.

an10.29:15.1.eng: There are four ways of practice.

an10.29:15.5.eng: pleasant practice with slow insight, and

an10.29:15.7.eng: These are the four ways of practice.

an10.29:16.1.pli: Etadaggaṃ, bhikkhave, imāsaṃ catunnaṃ paṭipadānaṃ yadidaṃ sukhā paṭipadā khippābhiññā.
an10.29:16.1.eng: The best of these four ways of practice is the pleasant practice with swift insight.

an10.29:16.2.eng: Some sentient beings practice like this.

an10.29:16.3.pli: Evaṃpaṭipannānampi kho, bhikkhave, sattānaṃ attheva aññathattaṃ atthi vipariṇāmo.
an10.29:16.3.eng: But even the sentient beings who practice like this decay and perish.

an10.29:16.4.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako tasmimpi nibbindati.
an10.29:16.4.eng: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with it.

an10.29:16.5.pli: Tasmiṃ nibbindanto agge virajjati, pageva hīnasmiṃ.
an10.29:16.5.eng: Their desire fades away even for the foremost, let alone the inferior.

an10.29:17.6.eng: One individual, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, perceives the dimension of nothingness.

an10.29:18.1.pli: Etadaggaṃ, bhikkhave, imāsaṃ catunnaṃ saññānaṃ yadidaṃ ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanameko sañjānāti.
an10.29:18.1.eng: The best of these four perceptions is when someone, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, perceives the dimension of nothingness.

an10.29:18.2.eng: Some sentient beings perceive like this.

an10.29:18.3.pli: Evaṃsaññīnampi kho, bhikkhave, sattānaṃ attheva aññathattaṃ atthi vipariṇāmo.
an10.29:18.3.eng: But even the sentient beings who perceive like this decay and perish.

an10.29:18.4.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako tasmimpi nibbindati.
an10.29:18.4.eng: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with it.

an10.29:18.5.pli: Tasmiṃ nibbindanto agge virajjati, pageva hīnasmiṃ.
an10.29:18.5.eng: Their desire fades away even for the foremost, let alone the inferior.

an10.29:19.1.pli: Etadaggaṃ, bhikkhave, bāhirakānaṃ diṭṭhigatānaṃ yadidaṃ ‘no cassaṃ, no ca me siyā, na bhavissāmi, na me bhavissatī’ti.
an10.29:19.1.eng: This is the best of the convictions of outsiders, that is: ‘I might not be, and it might not be mine. I will not be, and it will not be mine.’

an10.29:19.2.eng: When someone has such a view, you can expect

an10.29:19.3.pli: ‘yā cāyaṃ bhave appaṭikulyatā, sā cassa na bhavissati;
an10.29:19.3.eng: that they will not be attracted to continued existence,

an10.29:19.4.pli: yā cāyaṃ bhavanirodhe pāṭikulyatā, sā cassa na bhavissatī’ti.
an10.29:19.4.eng: and they will not be repulsed by the cessation of continued existence.

an10.29:19.5.eng: Some sentient beings have such a view.

an10.29:19.6.pli: Evaṃdiṭṭhīnampi kho, bhikkhave, sattānaṃ attheva aññathattaṃ atthi vipariṇāmo.
an10.29:19.6.eng: But even the sentient beings who have views like this decay and perish.

an10.29:19.7.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako tasmimpi nibbindati.
an10.29:19.7.eng: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with it.

an10.29:19.8.pli: Tasmiṃ nibbindanto agge virajjati, pageva hīnasmiṃ.
an10.29:19.8.eng: Their desire fades away even for the foremost, let alone the inferior.

an10.29:20.1.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā paramatthavisuddhiṃ paññāpenti.
an10.29:20.1.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who advocate the ultimate purity of the spirit.

an10.29:20.2.pli: Etadaggaṃ, bhikkhave, paramatthavisuddhiṃ paññapentānaṃ yadidaṃ sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an10.29:20.2.eng: This is the best of the advocates of the ultimate purity of the spirit, that is, when someone, going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, enters and remains in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

an10.29:20.3.pli: Te tadabhiññāya tassa sacchikiriyāya dhammaṃ desenti.
an10.29:20.3.eng: They teach Dhamma in order to directly know and realize this.

an10.29:20.4.eng: Some sentient beings have such a doctrine.

an10.29:20.5.pli: Evaṃvādīnampi kho, bhikkhave, sattānaṃ attheva aññathattaṃ atthi vipariṇāmo.
an10.29:20.5.eng: But even the sentient beings who have such a doctrine decay and perish.

an10.29:20.6.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako tasmimpi nibbindati.
an10.29:20.6.eng: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with it.

an10.29:20.7.pli: Tasmiṃ nibbindanto agge virajjati, pageva hīnasmiṃ.
an10.29:20.7.eng: Their desire fades away even for the foremost, let alone the inferior.

an10.29:21.1.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ paññāpenti.
an10.29:21.1.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who advocate ultimate extinguishment in this very life.

an10.29:21.2.pli: Etadaggaṃ, bhikkhave, paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ paññapentānaṃ yadidaṃ channaṃ phassāyatanānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ viditvā anupādā vimokkho.
an10.29:21.2.eng: This is the best of those who advocate extinguishment in this very life, that is, liberation by not grasping after truly understanding the origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape of the six fields of contact.

an10.29:21.3.pli: Evaṃvādiṃ kho maṃ, bhikkhave, evamakkhāyiṃ eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā asatā tucchā musā abhūtena abbhācikkhanti:
an10.29:21.3.eng: Though I state and assert this, certain ascetics and brahmins misrepresent me with the incorrect, hollow, false, untruthful claim:

an10.29:21.4.pli: ‘samaṇo gotamo na kāmānaṃ pariññaṃ paññāpeti, na rūpānaṃ pariññaṃ paññāpeti, na vedanānaṃ pariññaṃ paññāpetī’ti.
an10.29:21.4.eng: ‘The ascetic Gotama doesn’t advocate the complete understanding of sensual pleasures, forms, or feelings.’

an10.29:21.5.pli: Kāmānañcāhaṃ, bhikkhave, pariññaṃ paññāpemi, rūpānañca pariññaṃ paññāpemi, vedanānañca pariññaṃ paññāpemi, diṭṭheva dhamme nicchāto nibbuto sītibhūto anupādā parinibbānaṃ paññāpemī”ti.
an10.29:21.5.eng: But I do advocate the complete understanding of sensual pleasures, forms, and feelings. And I advocate full extinguishment by not grasping in this very life, wishless, quenched, and cooled.”

an10.3:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, an unethical person, who lacks ethics, has destroyed a vital condition for having no regrets.

an10.3:1.2.pli: avippaṭisāre asati avippaṭisāravipannassa hatūpanisaṃ hoti pāmojjaṃ;
an10.3:1.2.eng: When there are regrets, one who has regrets has destroyed a vital condition for joy.

an10.3:1.3.pli: pāmojje asati pāmojjavipannassa hatūpanisā hoti pīti;
an10.3:1.3.eng: When there is no joy, one who lacks joy has destroyed a vital condition for rapture.

an10.3:1.4.pli: pītiyā asati pītivipannassa hatūpanisā hoti passaddhi;
an10.3:1.4.eng: When there is no rapture, one who lacks rapture has destroyed a vital condition for tranquility.

an10.3:1.5.pli: passaddhiyā asati passaddhivipannassa hatūpanisaṃ hoti sukhaṃ;
an10.3:1.5.eng: When there is no tranquility, one who lacks tranquility has destroyed a vital condition for bliss.

an10.3:1.6.pli: sukhe asati sukhavipannassa hatūpaniso hoti sammāsamādhi;
an10.3:1.6.eng: When there is no bliss, one who lacks bliss has destroyed a vital condition for right immersion.

an10.3:1.7.pli: sammāsamādhimhi asati sammāsamādhivipannassa hatūpanisaṃ hoti yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ;
an10.3:1.7.eng: When there is no right immersion, one who lacks right immersion has destroyed a vital condition for true knowledge and vision.

an10.3:1.8.pli: yathābhūtañāṇadassane asati yathābhūtañāṇadassanavipannassa hatūpaniso hoti nibbidāvirāgo;
an10.3:1.8.eng: When there is no true knowledge and vision, one who lacks true knowledge and vision has destroyed a vital condition for disillusionment and dispassion.

an10.3:1.9.pli: nibbidāvirāge asati nibbidāvirāgavipannassa hatūpanisaṃ hoti vimuttiñāṇadassanaṃ.
an10.3:1.9.eng: When there is no disillusionment and dispassion, one who lacks disillusionment and dispassion has destroyed a vital condition for knowledge and vision of freedom.

an10.3:1.10.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, rukkho sākhāpalāsavipanno. Tassa papaṭikāpi na pāripūriṃ gacchati, tacopi … pheggupi … sāropi na pāripūriṃ gacchati.
an10.3:1.10.eng: Suppose there was a tree that lacked branches and foliage. Its shoots, bark, softwood, and heartwood would not grow to fullness.

an10.3:1.11.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, dussīlassa sīlavipannassa hatūpaniso hoti avippaṭisāro;
an10.3:1.11.eng: In the same way, an unethical person, who lacks ethics, has destroyed a vital condition for having no regrets.

an10.3:1.12.eng: When there are regrets, one who has regrets has destroyed a vital condition for joy. …

an10.3:1.13.eng: One who lacks disillusionment and dispassion has destroyed a vital condition for knowledge and vision of freedom.

an10.3:2.1.pli: Sīlavato, bhikkhave, sīlasampannassa upanisasampanno hoti avippaṭisāro;
an10.3:2.1.eng: An ethical person, who has fulfilled ethics, has fulfilled a vital condition for not having regrets.

an10.3:2.2.pli: avippaṭisāre sati avippaṭisārasampannassa upanisasampannaṃ hoti pāmojjaṃ;
an10.3:2.2.eng: When there are no regrets, one who has no regrets has fulfilled a vital condition for joy.

an10.3:2.3.pli: pāmojje sati pāmojjasampannassa upanisasampannā hoti pīti;
an10.3:2.3.eng: When there is joy, one who has fulfilled joy has fulfilled a vital condition for rapture.

an10.3:2.4.pli: pītiyā sati pītisampannassa upanisasampannā hoti passaddhi;
an10.3:2.4.eng: When there is rapture, one who has fulfilled rapture has fulfilled a vital condition for tranquility.

an10.3:2.5.pli: passaddhiyā sati passaddhisampannassa upanisasampannaṃ hoti sukhaṃ;
an10.3:2.5.eng: When there is tranquility, one who has fulfilled tranquility has fulfilled a vital condition for bliss.

an10.3:2.6.pli: sukhe sati sukhasampannassa upanisasampanno hoti sammāsamādhi;
an10.3:2.6.eng: When there is bliss, one who has fulfilled bliss has fulfilled a vital condition for right immersion.

an10.3:2.7.pli: sammāsamādhimhi sati sammāsamādhisampannassa upanisasampannaṃ hoti yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ;
an10.3:2.7.eng: When there is right immersion, one who has fulfilled right immersion has fulfilled a vital condition for true knowledge and vision.

an10.3:2.8.pli: yathābhūtañāṇadassane sati yathābhūtañāṇadassanasampannassa upanisasampanno hoti nibbidāvirāgo;
an10.3:2.8.eng: When there is true knowledge and vision, one who has fulfilled true knowledge and vision has fulfilled a vital condition for disillusionment and dispassion.

an10.3:2.9.pli: nibbidāvirāge sati nibbidāvirāgasampannassa upanisasampannaṃ hoti vimuttiñāṇadassanaṃ.
an10.3:2.9.eng: When there is disillusionment and dispassion, one who has fulfilled disillusionment and dispassion has fulfilled a vital condition for knowledge and vision of freedom.

an10.3:2.10.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, rukkho sākhāpalāsasampanno. Tassa papaṭikāpi pāripūriṃ gacchati, tacopi … pheggupi … sāropi pāripūriṃ gacchati.
an10.3:2.10.eng: Suppose there was a tree that was complete with branches and foliage. Its shoots, bark, softwood, and heartwood would grow to fullness.

an10.3:2.11.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, sīlavato sīlasampannassa upanisasampanno hoti avippaṭisāro;
an10.3:2.11.eng: In the same way, an ethical person, who has fulfilled ethics, has fulfilled a vital condition for not having regrets.

an10.3:2.12.eng: When there are no regrets, one who has no regrets has fulfilled a vital condition for joy. …

an10.3:2.13.eng: One who has fulfilled disillusionment and dispassion has fulfilled a vital condition for knowledge and vision of freedom.”

an10.30:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
an10.30:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

an10.30:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena rājā pasenadi kosalo uyyodhikā nivatto hoti vijitasaṅgāmo laddhādhippāyo.
an10.30:1.2.eng: Now at that time King Pasenadi of Kosala returned from combat after winning a battle and succeeding in his strategy.

an10.30:1.3.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo yena ārāmo tena pāyāsi.
an10.30:1.3.eng: Then King Pasenadi of Kosala went to the monastery.

an10.30:1.4.pli: Yāvatikā yānassa bhūmi, yānena gantvā yānā paccorohitvā pattikova ārāmaṃ pāvisi.
an10.30:1.4.eng: He went by carriage as far as the terrain allowed, then descended and entered the monastery on foot.

an10.30:1.5.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā bhikkhū abbhokāse caṅkamanti.
an10.30:1.5.eng: At that time several mendicants were walking mindfully in the open air.

an10.30:1.6.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo yena te bhikkhū tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā te bhikkhū etadavoca:
an10.30:1.6.eng: Then King Pasenadi of Kosala went up to them and said,

an10.30:1.7.pli: “kahaṃ nu kho, bhante, bhagavā etarahi viharati arahaṃ sammāsambuddho.
an10.30:1.7.eng: “Sirs, where is the Blessed One at present, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha?

an10.30:1.8.pli: Dassanakāmā hi mayaṃ, bhante, taṃ bhagavantaṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhan”ti.
an10.30:1.8.eng: For I want to see the Buddha.”

an10.30:1.9.pli: “Eso, mahārāja, vihāro saṃvutadvāro. Tena appasaddo upasaṅkamitvā ataramāno ālindaṃ pavisitvā ukkāsitvā aggaḷaṃ ākoṭehi; vivarissati te bhagavā dvāran”ti.
an10.30:1.9.eng: “Great king, that’s his dwelling, with the door closed. Approach it quietly, without hurrying; go onto the porch, clear your throat, and knock on the door-panel. The Buddha will open the door.”

an10.30:2.1.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo yena so vihāro saṃvutadvāro, tena appasaddo upasaṅkamitvā ataramāno ālindaṃ pavisitvā ukkāsitvā aggaḷaṃ ākoṭesi. Vivari bhagavā dvāraṃ.
an10.30:2.1.eng: So the king approached the Buddha’s dwelling, cleared his throat and knocked on the door-panel, and the Buddha opened the door.

an10.30:2.2.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo vihāraṃ pavisitvā bhagavato pādesu sirasā nipatitvā bhagavato pādāni mukhena ca paricumbati pāṇīhi ca parisambāhati nāmañca sāveti:
an10.30:2.2.eng: Then King Pasenadi entered the Buddha’s dwelling. He bowed with his head at the Buddha’s feet, caressing them and covering them with kisses, and pronounced his name:

an10.30:2.3.eng: “Sir, I am Pasenadi, king of Kosala!

an10.30:2.4.eng: I am Pasenadi, king of Kosala!”

an10.30:3.1.pli: “Kaṃ pana tvaṃ, mahārāja, atthavasaṃ sampassamāno imasmiṃ sarīre evarūpaṃ paramanipaccakāraṃ karosi, mettūpahāraṃ upadaṃsesī”ti?
an10.30:3.1.eng: “But great king, for what reason do you act with such utmost deference for this body, conveying your manifest love?”

an10.30:3.2.pli: “Kataññutaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhante, kataveditaṃ sampassamāno bhagavati evarūpaṃ paramanipaccakāraṃ karomi, mettūpahāraṃ upadaṃsemi.
an10.30:3.2.eng: “Sir, it’s because of my gratitude and thanks for the Buddha that I act with such utmost deference, conveying my manifest love.

an10.30:4.1.pli: Bhagavā hi, bhante, bahujanahitāya paṭipanno bahujanasukhāya bahuno janassa ariye ñāye patiṭṭhāpitā yadidaṃ kalyāṇadhammatāya kusaladhammatāya.
an10.30:4.1.eng: The Buddha is practicing for the welfare and happiness of the people. He has established many people in the noble system, that is, the principles of goodness and skillfulness.

an10.30:4.2.pli: Yampi, bhante, bhagavā bahujanahitāya paṭipanno bahujanasukhāya bahuno janassa ariye ñāye patiṭṭhāpitā yadidaṃ kalyāṇadhammatāya kusaladhammatāya, idampi kho ahaṃ, bhante, atthavasaṃ sampassamāno bhagavati evarūpaṃ paramanipaccakāraṃ karomi, mettūpahāraṃ upadaṃsemi.
an10.30:4.2.eng: This is a reason that I act with such utmost deference for the Buddha, conveying my manifest love.

an10.30:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhante, bhagavā sīlavā vuddhasīlo ariyasīlo kusalasīlo kusalasīlena samannāgato.
an10.30:5.1.eng: Furthermore, the Buddha is ethical, possessing ethical conduct that is mature, noble, and skillful.

an10.30:5.2.pli: Yampi, bhante, bhagavā sīlavā vuddhasīlo ariyasīlo kusalasīlo kusalasīlena samannāgato, idampi kho ahaṃ, bhante, atthavasaṃ sampassamāno bhagavati evarūpaṃ paramanipaccakāraṃ karomi, mettūpahāraṃ upadaṃsemi.
an10.30:5.2.eng: This is another reason that I act with such utmost deference for the Buddha, conveying my manifest love.

an10.30:6.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhante, bhagavā dīgharattaṃ āraññiko, araññavanapatthāni pantāni senāsanāni paṭisevati.
an10.30:6.1.eng: Furthermore, the Buddha lives in the wilderness, frequenting remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest.

an10.30:6.2.pli: Yampi, bhante, bhagavā dīgharattaṃ āraññiko, araññavanapatthāni pantāni senāsanāni paṭisevati, idampi kho ahaṃ, bhante, atthavasaṃ sampassamāno bhagavati evarūpaṃ paramanipaccakāraṃ karomi, mettūpahāraṃ upadaṃsemi.
an10.30:6.2.eng: This is another reason that I act with such utmost deference for the Buddha, conveying my manifest love.

an10.30:7.1.eng: Furthermore, the Buddha is content with any kind of robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.

an10.30:7.2.pli: Yampi, bhante, bhagavā santuṭṭho itarītaracīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhārena, idampi kho ahaṃ, bhante, atthavasaṃ sampassamāno bhagavati evarūpaṃ paramanipaccakāraṃ karomi, mettūpahāraṃ upadaṃsemi.
an10.30:7.2.eng: This is another reason that I act with such utmost deference for the Buddha, conveying my manifest love.

an10.30:8.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhante, bhagavā āhuneyyo pāhuneyyo dakkhiṇeyyo añjalikaraṇīyo anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassa.
an10.30:8.1.eng: Furthermore, the Buddha is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of greeting with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.

an10.30:8.2.pli: Yampi, bhante, bhagavā āhuneyyo pāhuneyyo dakkhiṇeyyo añjalikaraṇīyo anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassa, idampi kho ahaṃ, bhante, atthavasaṃ sampassamāno bhagavati evarūpaṃ paramanipaccakāraṃ karomi, mettūpahāraṃ upadaṃsemi.
an10.30:8.2.eng: This is another reason that I act with such utmost deference for the Buddha, conveying my manifest love.

an10.30:9.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhante, bhagavā yāyaṃ kathā abhisallekhikā cetovivaraṇasappāyā, seyyathidaṃ—appicchakathā santuṭṭhikathā pavivekakathā asaṃsaggakathā vīriyārambhakathā sīlakathā samādhikathā paññākathā vimuttikathā vimuttiñāṇadassanakathā, evarūpāya kathāya nikāmalābhī akicchalābhī akasiralābhī.
an10.30:9.1.eng: Furthermore, the Buddha gets to take part in talk about self-effacement that helps open the heart, when he wants, without trouble or difficulty. That is, talk about fewness of wishes, contentment, seclusion, aloofness, arousing energy, ethics, immersion, wisdom, freedom, and the knowledge and vision of freedom.

an10.30:9.2.pli: Yampi, bhante, bhagavā yāyaṃ kathā abhisallekhikā cetovivaraṇasappāyā, seyyathidaṃ—appicchakathā …pe… vimuttiñāṇadassanakathā, evarūpāya kathāya nikāmalābhī akicchalābhī akasiralābhī, idampi kho ahaṃ, bhante, atthavasaṃ sampassamāno bhagavati evarūpaṃ paramanipaccakāraṃ karomi, mettūpahāraṃ upadaṃsemi.
an10.30:9.2.eng: This is another reason that I act with such utmost deference for the Buddha, conveying my manifest love.

an10.30:10.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhante, bhagavā catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ ābhicetasikānaṃ diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārānaṃ nikāmalābhī akicchalābhī akasiralābhī.
an10.30:10.1.eng: Furthermore, the Buddha gets the four absorptions—blissful meditations in this life that belong to the higher mind—when he wants, without trouble or difficulty.

an10.30:10.2.pli: Yampi, bhante, bhagavā catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ ābhicetasikānaṃ diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārānaṃ nikāmalābhī akicchalābhī akasiralābhī, idampi kho ahaṃ, bhante, atthavasaṃ sampassamāno bhagavati evarūpaṃ paramanipaccakāraṃ karomi, mettūpahāraṃ upadaṃsemi.
an10.30:10.2.eng: This is another reason that I act with such utmost deference for the Buddha, conveying my manifest love.

an10.30:11.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhante, bhagavā anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati, seyyathidaṃ—ekampi jātiṃ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṃsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi anekepi saṃvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe: ‘amutrāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṅgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṃ; tatrāpāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṅgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati.
an10.30:11.1.eng: Furthermore, the Buddha recollects many kinds of past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. He remembers: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so he recollects his many kinds of past lives, with features and details.

an10.30:11.2.pli: Yampi, bhante, bhagavā anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati, seyyathidaṃ—ekampi jātiṃ dvepi jātiyo …pe… iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati, idampi kho ahaṃ, bhante, atthavasaṃ sampassamāno bhagavati evarūpaṃ paramanipaccakāraṃ karomi, mettūpahāraṃ upadaṃsemi.
an10.30:11.2.eng: This is another reason that I act with such utmost deference for the Buddha, conveying my manifest love.

an10.30:12.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhante, bhagavā dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe, sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti: ‘ime vata bhonto sattā kāyaduccaritena samannāgatā vacīduccaritena samannāgatā manoduccaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṃ upavādakā micchādiṭṭhikā micchādiṭṭhikammasamādānā, te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapannā; ime vā pana bhonto sattā kāyasucaritena samannāgatā vacīsucaritena samannāgatā manosucaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṃ anupavādakā sammādiṭṭhikā sammādiṭṭhikammasamādānā, te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapannā’ti, iti dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati …pe… yathākammūpage satte pajānāti.
an10.30:12.1.eng: Furthermore, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, the Buddha sees sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. He understands how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds. ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They denounced the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never denounced the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ He understands how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.

an10.30:12.2.pli: Yampi, bhante, bhagavā dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena …pe… yathākammūpage satte pajānāti, idampi kho ahaṃ, bhante, atthavasaṃ sampassamāno bhagavati evarūpaṃ paramanipaccakāraṃ karomi, mettūpahāraṃ upadaṃsemi.
an10.30:12.2.eng: This is another reason that I act with such utmost deference for the Buddha, conveying my manifest love.

an10.30:13.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhante, bhagavā āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
an10.30:13.1.eng: Furthermore, the Buddha has realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and lives having realized it with his own insight due to the ending of defilements.

an10.30:13.2.pli: Yampi, bhante, bhagavā āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ …pe… sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati, idampi kho ahaṃ, bhante, atthavasaṃ sampassamāno bhagavati evarūpaṃ paramanipaccakāraṃ karomi, mettūpahāraṃ upadaṃsemi.
an10.30:13.2.eng: This is another reason that I act with such utmost deference for the Buddha, conveying my manifest love.

an10.30:14.1.pli: Handa ca dāni mayaṃ, bhante, gacchāma.
an10.30:14.1.eng: Well, now, sir, I must go.

an10.30:14.2.eng: I have many duties, and much to do.”

an10.30:14.3.eng: “Please, great king, go at your convenience.”

an10.30:14.4.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmīti.
an10.30:14.4.eng: Then King Pasenadi got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.
